TITLE: For These New York Farmers, Harvest Time Means High Times
SUMMARY: In fields from Sag Harbor to Ithaca, a new crop ripened this fall: cannabis plants grown for recreational marijuana.

TITLE: ‘Black Wall Street’ Was Burned Down in 1921, but It’s Being Revived
SUMMARY: The second Black Venture Summit was held in Tulsa this year.

TITLE: In Cleveland, They’re Cooking Up a Gay Neighborhood From Scratch
SUMMARY: Restaurants, kitchen classes and gardening are key parts of an effort to create an L.G.B.T.Q. district that can help lift the area’s economy.

TITLE: Ashland Was Set to Be a Food Paradise. Then Came the Almeda Fire.
SUMMARY: Two years ago, the Almeda fire tore through southern Oregon. Many people haven’t fully recovered, but farmers, chefs and others have rallied to sustain the area.

TITLE: Pickleball Is Expanding. Tennis Is Mad.
SUMMARY: From New York to Hawaii, weekend athletes and government officials are taking part in a battle that goes beyond the fight for court space.

TITLE: How to Spend a Perfect Weekend in Santa Cruz
SUMMARY: What once felt like a quirky California pit stop is now a popular getaway destination. Here’s a guide to the city’s beaches, bars, bookshops and beyond.

TITLE: Building Your Personal Brand Has Its Drawbacks. Burnout, for One.
SUMMARY: Younger workers embraced the idea of a personal brand as a way to get ahead, and carve out some power and security in their careers. But posting through it has its drawbacks.

TITLE: Small Businesses Build Their Own Supply Chains
SUMMARY: They’re shifting to domestic sourcing and production, like some big manufacturers, but with at least one advantage the giants don’t have.

TITLE: The Fight for the Soul of Pilates
SUMMARY: Long after the death of Joseph Pilates, the exercise program’s magnetic founder, his disciples are battling over his legacy.

TITLE: New York City’s First Cannabis Boss Wants to Combat ‘Cannaphobia’
SUMMARY: Dasheeda Dawson, a native New Yorker, returns home to direct the effort to build cannabis businesses and to absorb the illegal market into the new legitimate one.

TITLE: Savoring Bourbon, and Its Storied History, in Northern Kentucky
SUMMARY: As new distilleries pop up across the United States, the region along the Ohio River remains a particularly exciting destination for spirits tourism.

TITLE: His Mom Labored on a Winery Under Apartheid. Now, He Owns One.
SUMMARY: Paul Siguqa grew up hating wineries because his mother toiled in their fields. But last year he opened the only fully Black-owned vineyard in Franschhoek, one of South Africa’s most prestigious wine towns.

TITLE: Silicon Valley Had Its Heyday. Can Tech Ecosystems Now Grow Inland?
SUMMARY: The AOL co-founder Steve Case sees a need for entrepreneurial hubs beyond the coasts. “Let’s have it be a few dozen cities,” he says.

TITLE: Silicon Valley Slides Back Into ‘Bro’ Culture
SUMMARY: Elon Musk, Mark Zuckerberg and Marc Andreessen show how the tech industry’s insular culture remains largely unchanged.

TITLE: Herbert Kohler, Plumbing Mogul Who Created a Golf Mecca, Dies at 83
SUMMARY: The billionaire chief of a family company known for its bathtubs, toilets and faucets, he brought championship play to a tiny Wisconsin town.

TITLE: A $100 Million Bet on Finding the Next ‘Mr. Beast’
SUMMARY: Reed Duchscher, the manager of the YouTube megastar “Mr. Beast,” is teaming up with the investment firm TCG to bankroll businesses led by online creators.

TITLE: Twilight of Entrepreneurs in China as More Leave the Country
SUMMARY: Two of China’s best-known entrepreneurs, Pan Shiyi and Zhang Xin, stepped down from their top jobs at the real estate development company they built.

TITLE: The New Wave of Tasting Menus Is Affordable and Approachable
SUMMARY: With lower price points and less attitude, chefs around the country are finding fun and freedom in the once-stuffy form.

TITLE: What if You Could Give Start-Up Money to People, Not Companies?
SUMMARY: The entrepreneurial Liberman siblings are testing out the concept — on themselves.

TITLE: Kazuo Inamori, Major Industrialist in Postwar Japan, Dies at 90
SUMMARY: Founding two giant companies, he helped turn his country into an economic giant while encouraging employees to approach work with an almost spiritual devotion.
